Title.evidence: Timing of Adjuvant Chemotherapy in Colorectal Cancer: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomization was computer-generated with allocation concealment.

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants had high-risk stage II or III nonmetastatic colorectal cancer and underwent curative surgery.

Intervention.evidence: They were randomized to 3 or 6 months of adjuvant chemotherapy with fluoropyrimidine and oxaliplatin.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the impact of chemotherapy timing on outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was disease-free survival over a median follow-up of 72 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was computer-generated with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This post hoc analysis of the phase 3 SCOT trial included 5719 patients from 244 centers in 6 countries.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Five-year disease-free survival was 78.0% in the early-start group compared to 73.2% in the late-start group (hazard ratio, 1.24; 95% CI, 1.06-1.46; P = .01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were similar between groups, with no significant difference in the total treatment period (odds ratio, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.65-1.04; P = .09) or the first cycle (odds ratio, 0.77; 95% CI, 0.56-1.09; P = .13).
